Green and efficient oxidative desulfurization of refractory S-compounds from liquid fuels catalyzed by chromium-based MIL-101 stabilized MoOx catalyst Ilkay Gumus Conceptualization Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b ⁎⁎ Yasar Karatas Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing c Mehmet Gülcan Conceptualization Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing c ⁎ a Advanced Technology Applied and Research Center, Mersin University, Mersin 33343, Turkey Advanced Technology Applied and Research Center Mersin University Mersin 33343 Turkey aAdvanced Technology Applied and Research Center, Mersin University, Mersin 33343, Turkey b Department of Basic Sciences, Faculty of Maritime, Mersin University, Mersin 33343, Turkey Department of Basic Sciences Faculty of Maritime Mersin University Mersin 33343 Turkey bDepartment of Basic Sciences, Faculty of Maritime, Mersin University, Mersin 33343, Turkey c Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Van Yüzüncü Yıl University, Van 65080, Turkey Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science Van Yüzüncü Yıl University Van 65080 Turkey cDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Van Yüzüncü Yıl University, Van 65080, Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Advanced Technology Applied and Research Center, Mersin University, Mersin 33343, Turkey. Advanced Technology Applied and Research Center Mersin University Mersin 33343 Turkey In this work, MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) a new composite material, involving the collaboration of MoOx and MIL-101(Cr) to remove the refractory S-compounds (RSCs) from fuels via oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process were successfully synthesized. The prepared catalyst was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDX), powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), N2 sorption measurement (BET) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The prepared MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was applied for the ODS of model fuel oil and showed the remarkably catalytic activity for the removal of RSCs from model fuel oil via oxidation. In addition, the effect of Mo-loading amount, H2O2/sulfur (O/S) molar ratio, and reaction temperature on the ODS reactivity were investigated. To explore the specific reaction mechanism of ODS over the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr), the effect of radical scavengers on ODS activity was examined. The radical scavengers experiments showed that the present oxidation reaction occurred through a radical mechanism involving the formation of •OH and •O2 ͞ species. In addition, it was found that the ODS efficiency is majorly related to the Mo5+ species forming with electron transfer to Mo6+ ion from Lewis acid sites of MIL-101(Cr). Furthermore, the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst possesses recycling performance and remarkable stability, and even after five recycles, the removal of DBT was >94.8%. Hence, it could be confirmed that MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) is very useful in the ODS to remove RSCs from fuels in the presence of H2O2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst MIL-101(Cr) MOFs Molybdenum Oxidative desulfurization 1 Introduction In spite of the enhancement popularity of new energy applications, nearly 90% of the world-wide energy resources are still provided from fossil fuels [1,2]. However, raw fossil fuels contain many contaminants such as inherently occurring S-containing organic compounds [3–6]. The combustion of sulfur compounds produces toxic SOx species and, in addition to their noxious effects on living organisms, causes serious health/environmental problems such as ecological instability, air and water pollution, and acid rains [7,8]. In addition to these problems, S-compounds in fuels are known to inactivate catalysts, causing damage and corrosion of metal refinery equipment such as pipelines and pumps [9]. Thus, in many countries, sulfur contents in fuel oils have been restricted to ultra-low levels (< 10 ppm) due to strict environmental regulations [2,10], and removal of those contaminants from the fuels before use has become one of the biggest concerns in recent years. Nowadays, hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a popular process used in the petroleum refining industry [11]. This methodology is effective in the removal of various S-containing compounds (disulfides, sulfides, thiol, etc.). However, HDS requires hard reaction conditions (p > 2500 kPa; T > 250 °C and high H2 consumption) to remove RSCs due to their electron density as well as the steric factor that exists around the sulfur atom [11,12]. Recently, alternative fuel desulfurization processes have also been intensively investigated to overcome the drawbacks of HDS [13–15]. In particular, the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process has been attracting researchers’ attention as a new technique owing to its benefits such as moderate operating procedure (atmospheric pressure in the absence of H2, etc.) as well as the prominent activity in removing RSCs [16–19]. Generally, ODS is a two-step process: (i) oxidation of S-containing compounds to their respective sulfoxides and/or sulfones with an oxidizing agent (such as t‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), cyclohexanone peroxide (CYHPO), cumene hydroperoxide (CHP), ozone, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), t‑butyl hypochlorite (t-BuOCl)) (ii) removal of oxidized end products from the oil using adsorbents or polar extractive solvent [20–23]. Among oxidants used, H2O2 is a favorite as an oxidant for ODS due to its low cost, high oxidation capacity, and environment-friendly. However, it should be noted that using a catalyst to activate H2O2 effectively during the oxidative process is still a challenge. The performance of ODS is always related to the nature of the catalyst. Thus, a key scientific issue to realize this technology is the development of high-performance catalysts. Up to now, many species of economical metal oxides (Ti(IV), W(VI), Mo(VI), and V(V) oxides, etc.) have been widely researched for the ODS purification process of fuels because of the distinctive chemical properties such as the adjustable charge states and stable structures [24–28]. Among them, MoO3, with outstanding catalytic activity, superior Lewis acidity, structural versatility, as well as cost-effective, has been widely used in recent years. What is more, the switchable oxidation states of MoO3 (Mo6+/Mo5+/Mo4+) make MoOx an excellent promoter for free radical reactions that can facilitate electron transfer between the substrate and support [29]. The MoOx with oxygen vacancies/defects can remarkably increase the oxidation of RSCs, activating hydrogen peroxide [30,31]. This is considered to be the driving force for the oxidation of RSCs. In addition, bulk MoO3 may exhibit poor catalytic performance in case of limited access to its active sites and severe aggregation [32]. To expose more active sites, immobilization of MoO3 on a proper carrier with a high specific surface can promote activity by increasing accessibility to active species. Recently, a class of porous hybrid materials, that are known as metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest for several applications thanks to the highly specific nature of their surface areas, tunable pore structure, unsaturated coordinative sites, and ready modification/functionalization [33–38]. The pores of MOFs can be used as an appropriate host to place and immobilize catalytically active species in their cavities [19,39,40]. The presence of coordinatively unsaturated Lewis acid regions/sites in the MOFs can also provide opportunities as anchoring points for the immobilization of active species via a post-synthetic modification [41]. On the other hand, it is known that the coordinatively unsaturated Lewis acid sites in frameworks can catalyze the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, generating the reactive oxygen species (hydroxyl and/or superoxide radicals) [19,42–44]. The generated radicals can be stabilized on the surface of MOFs and act as the main oxygen source for S-compounds. Thus far, the various structures of MOF have been employed as porous and flexible supports for the fuel purification process [Error! Bookmark not defined. [19,45]. The limited thermo-chemical durability of several MOFs can lead to drawbacks that hinder their activities. Besides, most MOFs with the microporous structure can restrict the rate of mass transfer as well as the admittance of substrates into their centers, which are catalytically active [46,47]. Therefore, producing robust MOFs structures having larger pore sizes is extremely significant for the effective removal of S-compounds via ODS. One of the highest hydrolytic stability among MOFs is chromium-based MIL-101 owing to the kinetic inertness of metal center (Cr3+) regarding ligand exchange [48–50]. Compared to an average MOF, it possesses a high surface area, with a SBET that is up to 4000 m2 g−1, large pore size, thermal and chemical resistance towards water, and various solvents. MIL-101(Cr) has also two different kinds of mesoporous cages (29 and 34 Å) that can be accessed via microporous windows (12 and 16 Å) [51–54]. Such features make MIL-101(Cr) ideal candidates for fast diffusion of bulky ODS substrates (particularly DBT and its derivatives) into the active sites. The pristine MIL-101(Cr) was applied as a catalyst for oxidative desulfurization of DBT and its derivatives [55]. However, it suffers from some drawbacks, such as the long induction period (6 h), the low initial S concentration (200 ppm), a long reaction time (24 h), and high temperature (120 °C) [55]. Considering the above facts, in the current research, we combined the large surface area of the MIL-101(Cr) support with the unique features of the molybdenum oxide and designed a new composite material, MoOx/MIL-101(Cr). To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports describing the use of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst in ODS processes. The ODS performance of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was investigated towards various RSCs (benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene), using H2O2, in a biphasic system. MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) displayed a remarkable performance in the conversion of S-compounds. Also, it was found that the ODS reactivity is majorly related to the existence of the active sites on the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) (Mo5+ and Cr3+) as well as the structure of the RSCs. What is more, the catalyst also has a very stable recycling ability, displaying a perfect expectation for application in the industry in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chromium trinitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3•9H2O, 99%), MoO2(acac)2 (Bis(acetylacetonato)dioxomolybdenum(VI)), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (C6H4-1,4-(CO2H)2, 98%), benzothiophene (C8H6S, BT, 98%), dibenzothiophene (C12H8S, DBT, 98%), 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (C14H12S, 4,6-DMDBT, 97%), H2O2 (34.5-36.5 wt%), acetonitrile (CH3CN, 99.8%), methanol (CH3OH, 99%), acetone (CH3COCH3, 99.5%), n-decane (CH3(CH2)8CH3, 99%) and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%) were procured from commercial providers and were used without further modification. 2.2 Synthesis of MIL-101(Cr) and MIL-101(Cr) supported MoOX catalyst The hydrothermal method, well known in the literature, was used to synthesize the MIL-101(Cr) host matrix [56–58]. To prepare of MIL-101(Cr) supported MoOx catalyst; as the metal precursor, MoO2(acac)2 was used to synthesize the MIL-101(Cr) supported catalyst by using an builded SIM (solvothermal deposition in MOFs) method [59]. MIL-101(Cr) (150 mg), MoO2(acac)2 (15.29 mg, 0.48 mmol), and methanol (3 mL) were added to a vial. To completely dissolve the Mo precursor, the mixture was ultrasonicated for 15 min. After, to control the Mo-loading amount on MIL-101(Cr) it was stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the obtained product was first collected and was then washed using methanol (3 × 20 mL) and acetone (3 × 20 mL), respectively. Finally, the product was thermally activated under a high vacuum for 8 h at 100 °C. The amount of Mo-loading was found to be 0.90 ± 0.01% (w/w) Mo on MIL-101(Cr). 2.3 Instrumentation The structures of the MIL-101(Cr) host material and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst were characterized by P-XRD, ICP-OES, SEM, SEM-Elemental mapping, FT-IR, N2 sorption measurement (BET), and XPS techniques (see details in the Supporting Information). 2.4 Oxidative desulfurization procedure First, the model oil, which has an S-content of approximately 1000 ppm, was prepared via the use of a specific amount of S-compounds in n-decane (50 mL). In a typical ODS process, 5 mL of model oil and 5 mL of acetonitrile (as an extracting solvent) was placed in a reaction tube and stirred for 10 min to get extraction equilibrium. Then, 25 mg of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) and 34.5–36.5% H2O2 (molar ratio of O/S=10) were added. The reaction was heated to the desired temperature was performed while stirring it at a constant speed. Samples from the acetonitrile and/or model oil phase for the quantification of the sulfur content were analyzed via the use of gas chromatography (GC). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization P-XRD, ICP-OES, SEM, SEM-Elemental Mapping, FT-IR, XPS and BET techniques were used to reveal structural and morphological features of MIL-101(Cr) host material and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst. First, ICP-OES analysis was performed to determine the amount of Mo supported on MIL-101(Cr), and the Mo content of prepared MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst was found to be 0.90 ± 0.01 wt% (theoretical loading 3.0 wt% Mo). MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst was synthesized by using MoO2(acac)2 precursor by depositing on MIL-101(Cr) surface with an easy, low-cost, and reproducible method. Fig. 1 presents the P-XRD patterns of bare MIL-101(Cr) and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) showing similar main diffraction peaks. In other words, the addition of MoO2(acac)2 to the synthetic medium of MIL-101(Cr) did not change the crystal structure of MIL-101(Cr). This means that the crystal structure of MIL-101(Cr) was well preserved following the addition of the MoO2(acac)2 [18,33,34]. The nonappearance of any diffraction ascribed to molibdenum can be explained by low loading wt% of Mo onto host material (containing 0.90 wt% Mo as determined by ICP-OES). In addition, Fig. S1 shows the P-XRD patterns of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) samples containing different amounts (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 wt% Mo) of molybdenum (0.32, 0.43, 0.72 and 0.90 wt% Mo loading) found in ICP-OES analysis. Evaluation of the P-XRD patterns clearly showed that the crystallinities of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) samples at different Mo loadings were very close to each other and new phases did not emerge. The FT-IR spectra of both MIL-101(Cr) and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) confirm the bands that were attributed to the solid support vibrations (Fig. 2 ). In Fig. 2, the peaks are seen at 1619 cm−1 which is compatible with the C=O stretching vibrations of the carboxyl group from terephthalic acid. Besides, the O-C-O symmetric stretching vibrations of the terephthalic acid were seen at 1405 cm−1. Furthermore, the aromatic C=C stretching vibrations were shown at 1508 cm−1 as a weak peak. When comparing the FT-IR spectrum of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst with MIL-101(Cr) spectrum; both of them have the peaks that were similar in the same region. Moreover, results such as these are considered as a sign that the chemical structure of MIL-101(Cr) has not been changed in the throughout the synthesis of the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) [33,34,50,56]. Also, two weak characterization vibrations were seen in the spectrum of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) at 941 cm−1 and 886 cm−1, which can be assigned to symmetrical and asymmetrical vibrations of O-Mo-O [60]. Furthermore, Fig. S2 depicts the FT-IR spectra of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) samples containing different amounts of molybdenum (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 wt% Mo). The results revealed that low Mo loading did not significantly change the spectra, as expected (containing 0.32, 0.43, 0.72 and 0.90 wt% Mo as determined by ICP-OES, respectively). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of MIL-101(Cr) and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst are presented in Fig. 3 to identify the presence of MoOx in the micropores (type I shape) of MIL-101(Cr) [61]. Table S1 presents a list of the textural features related to the MIL-101(Cr) and MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) samples, which have BET surface areas and maximum micro-pore volumes (Vμ), the pore sizes. During the proper incorporation of MoOx into MIL-101(Cr), partial decrease in both surface area (from 2442 m2 g−1 to 2432 m2 g−1) and total pore volume of MIL-101(Cr) (from 1.31 cm3 g−1 to 1.27 cm3 g−1) were observed. This should be associated with pore blockage of the MIL-101(Cr) by MoOx species or their accumulation on the cage windows of MIL-101(Cr) host material. Further, in the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig. 3) of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr), hysteresis loop did not observed that of MIL-101(Cr) framework. This showed that the procedure that was followed to ensure the synthesis of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) did not result in the production of any mesopores in MIL-101(Cr) framework [57,58]. SEM analysis and corresponding elemental mapping of the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst in Fig. 4 (a–h) shows the existence of Mo, Cr, C, and O in MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst, further verifying the incorporation of MoOx into MIL-101(Cr). XPS technique was used to investigate its the chemical composition as well as the valence states of active components in the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr). Fig. 5 demonstrates that C, O, Cr, and Mo elements are identified in the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst. Meantime, the deconvolution Mo 3d peak showed that two types of Mo element valences were present in the MoOx (Fig. 5(b)). The doublets observed at 231.11 and 234.18 eV the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 regions of the spectrum were ascribed to the Mo5+, whereas those observed at 231.91 and 234.91 eV are characteristic for Mo6+ valance state [29,62]. The presence of Mo5+ in the catalyst is caused by the formation of oxygen vacancies which are resulted from the metal-support interaction [21,63]. 3.2 ODS activity of the catalyst In this study, we purposed to evaluate the ODS performance of a new molybdenum based composite material anchored on the MIL-101(Cr) and chosen various RSCs (4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMBT)), dibenzothiophene (DBT), and benzothiophene (BT)) based on the commonly founded species in fuel feedstocks. At first, with the objective of optimizing the ODS conditions, the influence of some experimental parameters (amount of Mo loading, H2O2/sulfur molar ratio (O/S), reaction temperature/time) on the oxidation of RSCs was screened and the conversion of DBT as a model S-compound within an acetonitrile/decane biphasic system was selected to be the benchmark reaction. The first reaction for the conversion of DBT was conducted, carried out in the presence of 3%-MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst with a H2O2/Sulfur (O/S) ratio of 8 at 30 °C and after 90 min, the conversion of DBT was only 33%. It is well known that the oxidation of DBT increases at high temperatures owing to the formation of active metallic peroxides increases at high temperatures [64]. Therefore, the oxidation of DBT at higher temperatures (i.e. 45, 60, and 75 °C) was performed to determine the optimum reaction temperature (Fig. 6 (a)). The results showed that with an increase in the reaction temperature from 30 to 60 °C, the DBT conversion rate gradually increased from 33% to 86% within a reaction time of 90 min, as given in Fig. 6(a). This can be attributed to the activation of acidic surface groups (catalytically active species), and the increase in the system thermodynamic, which resulted in an increased mass transfer, resulting in diffusion inside of the pores in the direction of the active centers [65]. In contrast, when the temperature was enhanced to 75 °C, the ODS rate of DBT did not considerably change which can likely be based on the increased decomposition of H2O2 at a higher temperature. By the way, no oxidation of DBT was observed in the presence of H2O2 without the use of catalyst at 60 °C, indicating that MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) acts as a catalyst in the reaction. In the ODS, another key parameter that can be used in the evaluation of the desulfurization performance of the catalyst is the O/S ratio (Fig. 6(b)). Theoretically, the oxidation of DBT to DBT sulfone (DBTO2) requires 2 equivalents of H2O2. However, most ODS processes to get effective removal of S-compounds need a high O/S ratio as a result of side reactions, which contain the thermal decomposition of the H2O2. In order to gain more understanding, the ODS performance of 3%-MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was also evaluated under reaction conditions with different H2O2/DBT molar ratios (i.e. 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12). Fig. 6(b) shows the effect of the O/S molar ratio on the removal of DBT from the model oil. The results indicated that in the O/S ratio, an increment from 2 to 10 affected the oxidation of DBT, increasing dramatically from 12 to 92%. However, with a further increase of the O/S (i.e. 12), the desulfurization activity was observed to decrease slightly (90%). Even though the desulfurization activity increases with the increase of H2O2, the water produced from the decomposition of excess H2O2 can reduce the reaction rate as it blocks the catalytically active sites [62]. The results obtained showed that the amount of H2O2 has a significant effect on ODS reactions and must be balanced to be able to effectively remove the S-compounds. The performances of the ODS catalysts depend significantly on the amount of metal loading since they form catalytically active metallic peroxide species during the ODS process. Therefore, the effect that of Mo loading as the active metal on the catalytic performance was investigated. In this regard, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 wt% Mo contents were prepared and evaluated for conversion reactions of DBT using the O/S ratio of 10 at 60 °C. It was found that the conversion of DBT increased from 36 to 99% gradually when the amount of Mo loading was raised from 0.5 to 3.0 wt% as a result of more active metallic peroxide intermediate species being present (Fig. 7 (a)). As a result, the 3 wt%-MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was chosen as a favorable catalyst and used for further optimization studies. Meanwhile, in the ODS reaction, pristine MIL-101 achieved 28% removal of DBT, which was significantly lower than catalysts with Mo-containing components. This indicated that Mo species act as key active sites during ODS reactions. Once the optimum catalyst has been determined, the time-dependent ODS reaction of DBT was monitored to determine the optimum reaction time. As presented in Fig. 7(b), the removal of DBT via MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) proceeded for 90 min. The DBT conversion was about 48% within 15 min, and the conversion reached 99% within 90 min. Thus, 90 min was considered to be an optimal reaction time (Fig. 7(b). It is well known that besides DBT, various RSCs are also available in real fuel oils [2,3,66]. For this reason, it was necessary to investigate the ODS process over the prepared catalyst for the various RSCs. BT and 4,6-DMDBT widely existed in diesel were chosen as the additional substrates to discuss. Under the determined reaction conditions, oxidative removal of the S-compounds showed a decrease in the following order: DBT > 4,6-DMDBT > BT with 99%, 92%, and 52%, respectively, which is consistent some reported porous catalysts (Fig. 8 ) [43,67]. In the ODS process, the conversion/removal of RSCs depends on the electron density around the S-atom, and reactivity is often increased via an increase in the electron density on the S-atom. The electron density onto the S-atom of DBT, 4,6-DMDBT and BT is 5.760, 5.793, and 5.739, respectively [68]. Thereby, the order of activity observed (DBT > BT; except 4,6-DMDBT) can be associated with the electron density on the S-atom. On the other hand, the lower activity of 4,6-DMDBT with a higher electron density on the S-atom when compared to the DBT may have been due to the large steric effect caused by the two -CH3 groups on the aromatic rings [44]. In order to evaluate the relative performance of the prepared MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) in the present ODS reaction, previous studies based on Mo-based catalysts were compared, as can be seen in Table 1 . It was observed that most of the catalysts were effective in ODS reactions at ≥60 °C. Among the Mo-based catalysts, when comparing by taking into consideration performances, including the initial concentration of DBT, conversion of DBT, TOF, oxidant type, and reaction temperature, the designed MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) might be considered as one of the most active catalysts. Because, MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) possess the highest TOF (44.36 h−1), compared to reported Mo-based catalysts for ODS with H2O2 under mild reaction conditions. On the other hand, although some Mo-based catalysts performed well in ODS, the reactions have mainly been done with strong oxidizers such as TBHP and CHP. The reusability of 3 wt%-MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was examined for the removal of DBT as the representative S-compound. After each of the ODS reactions, the catalyst was washed using acetonitrile to remove of sulfone product and reused in the next run. Fig. 9 illustrates the performance of the 3wt%- MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) for five repeated cycles after the regeneration of the catalyst. Following five reuse cycles, MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) still indicated remarkable catalytic activity with yields of 94.8%. MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst that was harvested from catalytic run 5 was analyzed by SEM. From the results, it was shown that no obvious changes existed in the morphology of the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst (Fig. S3). P-XRD pattern was used in determining the stability of the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) composite material. The XRD patterns from both the fresh and regenerated catalysts that were obtained at the end of catalytic cycle 5 were compared (Fig. S4). The results confirmed that the crystallinity of the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) remained unchanged after recycling. The results were an indication that the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst exhibited stability with regard to the current removal of the DBT and it is possible for it to be reused for use in multiple runs of the removal of DBT as the representative S-compound. 3.3 Analysis of the oxidation products and the proposed mechanism To understand the mechanism of desulfurization, the oxidation products of the studied RSCs after reaction were analyzed. For this, the oil phase and the solid catalyst were separated by centrifugation and tested by GC–MS (Fig. S5). The GC-MS results indicated that the oxidation products of DBT, 4,6-DMDBT and BT after oxidation were DBTO2 (m/z = 216.0), 4,6-DMDBTO2 (m/z = 244.1) (Fig. S6), and BTO2 (m/z = 166.0), respectively. No additional peaks for RSCs final products were seen in both phases, illustrating that S-compounds had been completely oxidized into the related sulfones as only products and completely retained within the catalyst phase. In the ODS, mechanistic routes are related to the active metal species within the catalyst as well as the oxidant type. It is well known that peroxides-mediated ODS reactions can generally proceed with two possible reaction pathways: the heterolytic (formation of metal-peroxo or two-electron process) or homolytic (formation of free radicals i.e. ·O2 ͞ or ·OH or one-electron process) cleavage of the O–O bond of the peroxide [17,50,73,78]. Mo-based catalysts usually prone to the formation of Mo-peroxo species by the heterolytic process. In the case of the formation of metal-peroxo species, S-compounds are oxidized to related sulfoxides and/or sulfone via electrophilic attack of active peroxo-species to S-atom. But in some cases, the switchable oxidation states (Mo6+/Mo5+/Mo4+) of Mo let MoOx to be an excellent promoter for free radical reactions [67]. In other words, MoOx catalyzes the decomposition of H2O2 to generate a large number of radicals, leading to S-compounds oxidizing subsequently [79]. At the same time, the Lewis acid sites of MIL-101(Cr) can also catalyze the decomposition of H2O2, generating reactive oxygen radicals (·O2 ͞ or/and ·OH). Such radicals with free electrons are able to oxidize S-compounds via nucleophilic attack to the related sulfoxides and/or sulfones. To suggest a plausible mechanism and the key reactive species over the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr), radical quenching experiments were performed with dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) as the ·OH and ·O2 ͞ radical scavengers, respectively (H2O2:scavenger = 1:2). Compared with the scavenger-free experiment, the desulfurization activity by the addition of p-BQ leads to a noticeable decrease from 99 to 54%. Thereby, ·O2 ͞ was present in the ODS system as a significant reactive species during ODS reaction and involved in the oxidation of DBT. Besides, when DMSO was used as the scavenger for ·OH, the desulfurization activity stopped completely. From the results obtained, it was concluded that the ·OH and the ·O2 ͞ species played a major role in DBT oxidation in this catalytic ODS process, and the ·OH radical is dominant (Fig. S7). However, the blank MIL-101(Cr) experiment showed considerable desulfurization performance (26%) which could be ascribed to the existence of additional active sites (or, another route) in the MIL-101(Cr). Therefore, radical quenching experiments were also carried out using pure MIL-101 as a catalyst. Similar to the above results, the addition of DMSO and BQ negatively affected the conversion of DBT, indicating that pure MIL-101 also promotes the formation of ·OH and ·O2 ͞ radicals during the reaction (Fig. S7). Based on the surface electronic structure of MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) and radical scavenger experiments, the possible mechanism of ODS has been proposed as in Fig. 10 . Here, generation of reactive oxygen species from active centers in the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) can be based on the former observations supporting the formation of OH and ·O2 ͞ species via decomposition of peroxo-metallic species forming in the presence of H2O2 [74,80]. In the current ODS process, the presence of Mo5+ species and oxygen vacancies on MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) behaves as the primary active species. Hence, the ODS process starts with the chemical adsorption of the peroxy oxygen atom of oxidant to the oxygen vacancy on the metal oxide, formating a coordinated 5-member ring [74,81]. The high electron density, forming Mo5+ active sites due to the electron transfer from MIL-101(Cr) to MoO3 transfers to the peroxy O atom, causing OO and/or OH bond cleavages. These OO and OH bond cleavages result in the formation of •O2 ͞ and ·OH radicals, respectively. A similar route runs via Lewis acid sites (coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+sites forming by removing the terminal water molecules) in MIL-101(Cr). During the ODS, the unsaturated Cr3+ sites acting as Lewis acid react with H2O2 to generate peroxo-metallic Cr-O-OH species.43 The O−O bond cleavage in CrOOH results in the formation of ·OH radicals via heating conditions. Additionally, the further reaction of Cr-O· and H2O2 leads to the formation of ·O2 ͞ radicals. At last, due to the strong relationship between the S-atom and the oxygen, the DBT is then be oxidized via the ·O2 ͞ and ·OH radicals generated from the activation of H2O2 on the surface of the catalyst to the DBT sulfoxide (DBTO). The DBTO, which is thermodynamically unstable, reacts with the other active oxygen species to provide sulfone (DBTO2), which is the final product. Conclusion In summary, a novel MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst was fabricated by a simple, low-cost and reproducible method for the ODS of model oil. The prepared MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) showed a good catalytic performance for the ODS reaction (the removing of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT resulted in 99% (TOF = 44.36 h−1) and 92% (TOF = 41.22 h−1) within a 90 min, respectively). On the contrary, the removal efficiency for BT (52%) was not as good as that of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT possibly due to the reduction in the electron density on the S-atom of the BT. The results showed that high electron density on the S-atom of the S-compounds is very significant, suggesting the importance of the electrophilic addition of oxygen atoms via S-atom onto the S-compounds. The prepared catalyst could be reused five times to remove DBT without a significant reduction in the catalytic activity. In addition, radical quenching experiments were carried out to detect the main reactive species during the ODS process. The radical scavenger experiments showed that mostly ·OH species were responsible for the excellent catalytic activity. Finally, based on the radical quenching experiments, the mechanism of the oxidation process was proposed. coredata.dc:description: In this work, MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) a new composite material, involving the collaboration of MoOx and MIL-101(Cr) to remove the refractory S-compounds (RSCs) from fuels via oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process were successfully synthesized. The prepared catalyst was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDX), powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), N2 sorption measurement (BET) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The prepared MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) was applied for the ODS of model fuel oil and showed the remarkably catalytic activity for the removal of RSCs from model fuel oil via oxidation. In addition, the effect of Mo-loading amount, H2O2/sulfur (O/S) molar ratio, and reaction temperature on the ODS reactivity were investigated. To explore the specific reaction mechanism of ODS over the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr), the effect of radical scavengers on ODS activity was examined. The radical scavengers experiments showed that the present oxidation reaction occurred through a radical mechanism involving the formation of •OH and •O2 ͞ species. In addition, it was found that the ODS efficiency is majorly related to the Mo5+ species forming with electron transfer to Mo6+ ion from Lewis acid sites of MIL-101(Cr). Furthermore, the MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) catalyst possesses recycling performance and remarkable stability, and even after five recycles, the removal of DBT was >94.8%. Hence, it could be confirmed that MoOx/MIL-101(Cr) is very useful in the ODS to remove RSCs from fuels in the presence of H2O2.
coredata.dc:title: Green and efficient oxidative desulfurization of refractory S-compounds from liquid fuels catalyzed by chromium-based MIL-101 stabilized MoOx catalyst
